10.1016/j.apcata.2024.119702 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of POP, Ag(I)@POP-6.52, and Ag(0)@POP-6.52. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM, TEM and HRTEM micrographs of POP (a, d), Ag(I)@POP-6.52 (b, e h and j) and Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (c, f, k and m). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of POP, Ag(I)@POP-6.52, and Ag(0)@POP-6.52. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of POP, Ag(I)@POP-6.52, and Ag(0)@POP-6.52. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Effect of base dosage (a), oxygen pressure (b), catalyst dosage (c), and reaction temperature and time (d) on the HMF oxidation to HMFCA. Reaction conditions: HMF (0.252 g, 2.0 mmol), Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (0.1 mmol, based on the silver atom), Na2CO3 (2 equiv), H2O (40.0 mL), P O 2 (2.0 MPa), 100 °C, 90 min. a: with base dosage from 0 eq to 4 eq); b: with oxygen pressure from 0 MPa to 4 MPa; c: with catalyst dosage from 0 eq to 0.09 eq; d: with different reaction temperature and time. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Time-yield plots of HMF-to-HMFCA conversion existence Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (solid circle) or removing Ag(0)@POP-6.52 after 30 min (hollow circle) (a) and recyclability of the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 for HMF oxidation (b). Reaction conditions: HMF (0.252 g, 2.0 mmol), Ag(0)@POP (0.1 mmol, based on the silver atom), Na2CO3 (2 equiv), H2O (40.0 mL), P O 2 (2.0 MPa), 100 °C, 90 min. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 SEM (a: fresh catalyst; b: after five times reused), XRD (c), and FT-IR (d) patterns of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. Efficient aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid over porphyrin-based porous organic polymer-supported Ag nanoparticle catalysts Zhi Cao Writing – original draft Supervision Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ 1 Yin Wang Data curation a 1 Chao Liu Data curation a Haitao Cao Methodology Data curation a Zhongfei Han Investigation Funding acquisition a Tao Shen Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition b Gang Qi Supervision a a School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yancheng Institute of Technology, Yancheng, China School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yancheng Institute of Technology Yancheng China School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yancheng Institute of Technology, Yancheng, China b College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, China College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University Nanjing China College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Made the same contribution to this work. A series of porphyrin-based porous organic polymer-supported Ag nanoparticle, Ag(0)@POP-x were prepared by the reaction pathway of ion coordination followed by hydrogen reduction. The resulting composite Ag(0)@POP-6.52 shows excellent catalytic performance toward the selective oxidation of HMF to HMFCA, and an impressive HMFCA yield of 97.2% (Na2CO3 2 eq, O2 2.0 MPa 90 min, 100 °C). Analysis techniques such as ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, and XPS was employed to characterize the structure and properties of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. The reaction conditions including the type of base and solvent, base and catalyst dosage, oxygen pressure, reaction temperature and time were studied in detail to improve the yield of HMFCA. Furthermore, the catalytic stability of the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was evaluated by leaching and reusing tests, the results shows that the catalyst has good stability and robustness structure. Finally, the other aldehydes oxidation over Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was tested for investigation the substrate scope of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. Graphical Abstract A series of porphyrin-based porous organic polymer-supported Ag nanoparticle, Ag(0)@POP-x were prepared by the reaction pathway of ion coordination followed by hydrogen reduction. An excellent HMFCA yield of 97.2% was achieved over Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (Na2CO3 2 eq, O2 2.0 MPa 90 min, 100 °C) in water. The catalytic performance of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 is well maintained even after five catalytic cycles of HMF oxidation. XRD, SEM, and FT-IR was employed to characterize the structure and properties of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 before and after reaction, the results indicated that the structure of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 catalyst is highly stable even under harsh conditions Keywords HMF HMFCA Heterogeneous silver catalysts Porous organic polymer Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The exploration of abundant and renewable biomass for energy, materials, fuels, and chemicals has been a priority in worldwide research in recent years since the depleting fossil fuel reserves and increasing greenhouse gas emission [1–4]. In this regard, carbohydrate-based platform chemicals, especially the HMF has promoted extensive studies on its synthesis due to the high reactivity and can be used as a promising candidate for the production of a wide range of furanic compounds [5–9]. These compounds include 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) and 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) synthesized by selective hydrogenation and 2,5-diformethylfuran (DFF), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) and 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) produced through selective oxidation. In which, HMFCA, a less known oxidative product, is highly relevant compound in the production of furanic polyesters [10,11] and for the synthesis of an interleukin inhibitor [12] as well having antitumoral activities [13]. As shown in Scheme 1, it is a challenge protocol to selectively oxidize the aldehyde group in the HMF structure without affecting the groups of -OH, and furan ring [14–16]. Cannizzaro reaction, a strong base-induced intermolecular hydride-transfer reaction of an aldehyde (lacking the hydrogen atom at α-position) [17], can promote one molecule of HMF oxidizes to the HMFCA and another one is reduced to the BHMF, with a maximum HFCA yield limited to 50% is obtained [18,19]. Beside the Cannizzaro reaction, a variety of heterogeneous metal catalysts have been applied for HMFCA preparation [20–22]. HMF was reported to be selectively converted into HMFCA (H2O, NaHCO3 2 eq, O2 10 bar, 90 °C, 12 h reaction, ca. 93% yield) employing a carbon-supported gold catalysts (Au/HSAG) [20]. The photocatalytic methodology mediated was proposed, 90% and 96.7% selectivity of HMFCA had been achieved over Au/TiO2 [21] and Ag/TiO2 [22], respectively. Various noble metal catalysts including Au, Pt, Ru, and Pd have been successfully used for HMF oxidation [23–25], however, these catalysts generally shown low selectivity due to over-oxidation to FDCA, hence resulting in poor HMFCA yields [15,26]. Zhang et al. developed a protocol to selectively converted HMF into HMFCA using an immobilized molybdenum acetylacetonate complex (K-10 clay-Mo), 90.3%, 92.5% and 89.2% yield of HMFCA were obtained under the optimized conditions using p-chlorotoluene, toluene, and trifluorotoluene as solvent, respectively [27]. Fergani et al. prepared a series of new heterogeneous catalysts, MOx@Nb-zeolite catalysts (where MOx = CoOx, MnOx or FeOx) for selective oxidation of HMF to HMFCA, a 97.0% selectivity of HMFCA with about 95% conversion of HMF was achieved under the catalysis of Mn@Nb-Y30 in acetonitrile using t-BuOOH as oxidizing agent [28]. The use of aromatic organic solvents and stoichiometric oxidant which however affects the sustainability of these catalytic systems [14,15]. As mentioned above, it is of a great significance to use high selectivity catalyst and more environmentally friendly solvent for the aerobic oxidation of HMF into HMFCA. According to the reports, silver-based catalysts allow the quantitative conversion of HMF to HFCA in water under mild reaction conditions [14,15,29–35]. Recently, commercially available Ag2O has been used as a potentially useful catalyst for oxidation of HMF to HMFCA, and an impressive yield of HMFCA (98%) in 60 min at 90 °C with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as oxidizing agent, using microwave heating could shorten the reaction time to 24 min [15]. However, the test of catalyst reusability displayed that Ag2O would be deactivated due to the reduction of silver oxide to metallic silver and nanoparticles sintering during the reaction. Indeed, Ag nanoparticle catalysts usually exhibit size-dependent effect, as well as surface and macroscopic quantum tunneling effect [29]. Biosynthesized Ag NP was also developed by Kargar et al., for HMFCA productionand, a yield of 98% for HMFCA a conversion rate of 100% for 5-HMF were achieved using TEMPO as oxidizing agent in deep eutectic substrate [30]. In an another of their work, 98% yield of HMFCA with 99% conversion of 5-HMF was achieved using H2O2 as oxidizing agent in H2O [31]. However, stoichiometric oxidant was need in there two catalytic systems. Supported or capped is an effective strategy to protect Ag NPs from aggregation. Schade et al. loaded Ag onto ZrO2 by deposition-precipitation-reduction methods, Ag/ZrO2 display higher efficient for HMFCA production, 84% yield of HMFCA was still achieved after three times reused (fresh, 98%) [32]. Poly-(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) was reported act as a capping/stabilizing agent to improve the stability of Ag NPs [33,34]. Recently, Su et al. supported silver oxide on calcium carbonate to increase the reusability of the catalyst, 85% HMFCA yield was achieved under optimum condition. Unfortunately, significant reduction in activity was observed after four times reused (HMFCA yield decreased from 85% to 50%) attributed to the formation of CaCO3 aqueous slurry during the reaction [35]. Excellent yield of HMFCA could be achievable over these homogeneous silver catalysts, however, the stability of traditional heterogeneous base is very poor, which would lead to the deactivation of Ag NPs due to the leaching and aggregating of the catalyst species [35,36]. Covalent organic frameworks (COF) are built from organic linkers via the covalent bonds with the performance of excellent stability, high surface areas, and large pores, and can be widely used in various fields [37,38]. Recently, Shi et al. reported a COF TzDa/AgBr, prepared by in-situ precipitation-deposition of AgBr onto COF TzDa, which shown high activity and stability during the recycled treatment and degradation of antibiotics tetracycline [39]. However, to the best of our knowledge, there are few works concentrated on HMFCA production with Ag@COF catalyst. Within this study, the immobilization of uniform and highly dispersed Ag NPs over POP (polymerization of pyrrole and p-benzaldehyde) via the reaction pathway of ion coordination followed by hydrogen reduction ( Scheme 2). The resulting composite Ag(0)@POP-6.52 shows excellent catalytic performance toward the selective oxidation of HMF to HMFCA. Analysis techniques such as ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, and XPS was employed to characterize the structure and properties of the Ag(0)@POP-6.52. The reaction conditions including the type of base and solvent, base and catalyst dosage, oxygen pressure, reaction temperature and time were studied in detail to improve the yield of HMFCA. In addition, the catalytic stability of the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was evaluated by leaching and reusing tests on the HMF oxidation. Finally, the other aldehydes oxidation over Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was tested for investigation the substrate scope of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. We anticipate that these results can drive progress in the silver catalyzed selective oxidation of aldehydes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pyrrole (99%), p-benzaldehyde (98%), propionic acid (99.5%), silver acetate (98%), silver oxide (99.99%) nano-TiO2 (60 nm, 99.7%), and nano-Al2O3 (150 nm, 99.9%) were analytical grade and purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). MCM-41 was purchased from Tianjin Yuanli Chemical Co., Ltd (Tianjin, China). HMF (>99%), HMFCA (>99%), FDCA (>99%), DFF (99%), FFCA (>99%) of chromatographic grade were obtained from Sigma (Shanghai, China). Other reagents and solvents of analytical grade were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China) and used without further purification unless otherwise noted. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The silver content was tested using Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer Optima 3000 V). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were recorded in the range of 10 °≤ 2θ ≤ 90 ° on PANalytical X′Pert3 Powder (Panaco, Netherlands) using Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15432 nm). N2 adsorption-desorption was obtained on Beckman Coulter SA3100 (Beckman Coulter, America). The surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the total pore volume was estimated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) at P/P0 = 0.99. SEM micrographs were recorded on a Nova NanoSEM 450 scanning electron microscope (FEI, America) and TEM micrographs were recorded on a JEOL JEM-1400plus transmission electron microscope (Jpanese Electronics). XPS analysis were recorded on a ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo, America). 2.3 Catalyst preparation POP supporter was synthesized by polymerization of pyrrole and p-benzaldehyde under acidic conditions. Briefly, freshly distilled pyrrole (5.0 g, 74.5 mmol), terephthaldehyde (5.0 g, 37.3 mmol), and 150 mL propionic acid were charged into a 200 mL Teflon lined autoclave. After react for 6 h at 70 °C and then hydrothermal treatment for 12 h at 120 °C. After cooling the reactor to room temperature, the resulting dark brownish precipitate was ﬁltered and washed by Soxhlet extraction for 24 h with water. Then 7.4 g POP was obtained after drying the washed material at 80 °C for 12 h (86.5% yield based on terephthaldehyde). Ag(0)@POP-x (x, the Ag loaded on POP) were synthesized as follow: POP supporter (2.0 g) and designed mount of silver acetate were refluxed in 100 mL DMF at 150 °C for 8 h. After cooled the mixture to room temperature, the resulting samples, Ag(I)@POP-x, was recovered by filtration and then dried at 60 °C overnight after thoroughly washed with water. Finally, Ag(0)@POP-x catalyst was obtained after reduced the Ag(I)@POP-x under H2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 4 h. Ag@TiO2 was synthesized by immersion followed by pyrolysis and reduction. Briefly, 1.0 g TiO2 was dispersed in 50 mL of deionized water, 77 mg of silver acetate added to the suspension, then the mixture was stirred at 400 rpm for 90 min. After that, the water was removed by heating to 80°C to obtain the samples with 5 wt% Ag loading. Finally, the Ag@TiO2 catalyst was obtained calcined the impregnated catalysts in static air for 2 h at 823 K followed by reduced under H2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 4 h. The same procedure for 5 wt% Ag on SiO2, and Al2O3 was realized. 2.4 Oxidation of HMF The oxidation of HMF was carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical run, HMF (0.252 g, 2.0 mmol) along with Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (5 mol%, based on Ag), Na2CO3 (0.424 g, 4.0 mmol), and H2O (20.0 mL) was introduced into the steel reactor. After purging the reactor three times with oxygen, and then closed the outlet valve to maintain 2.0 MPa of oxygen pressure (ambient temperature). After the reaction was conducted at 100 °C for 90 min with a stirring speed of 400 rpm, the catalyst was recovered through filtration and designated as R-Ag(0)@POP-6.52, the mixture was decanted into a volumetric flask using water as diluent. HMF and HMFCA in the reaction medium were analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Auno LC2000) equipped with UV detector (270 nm) with C-18 column (Thermo Aquasil-C18, 5 μm × 4.6 × 250 mm, SN:10890784) at 25 °C with 1 mL min−1 acetonitrile-acetic acid aqueous (1 wt%) mixture (3:7, v/v) as the mobile phase. The HMF conversion (mol%), HMFCA yield (mol%) and selectivity were calculated basis on the following formulas: HMF conversion (mol%): (1) H M F c o n v e r s i o n = ( 1 − mol of remaining H M F m o l of starting H M F ) × 100 % HMFCA yield (mol%): (2) H M F C A y i e l d = moles of HMFCA in product moles of H M F loaded in the reaction × 100 % HMFCA selectivity (mol%): (3) HMFCA selectivity = moles of HMFCA produced moles of H M F converted × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The Ag content in Ag(0)@POP-x was detected by ICP-OES and the results are listed in Table 1. Interestingly, the recovery rate of silver based on ICP-OES is almost consistent (88.7–87.2%) with the mass ratio of silver acetate/POP input in the range of 0.025–0.125. After this, a significantly reduction of the rate of silver recovery is observed with further increase of silver acetate input. However, no silver was contained in the POP ( Table 2, entry 1), combined with XPS results (see in Fig. 4b), it can be concluded that Ag NPs have been successfully anchored onto the POP surface mainly through the N atom. The XRD patterns of the POP shows that no evidence of the crystalline phases was formed (Fig. 1). For the Ag(I)@POP-6.52, several diffraction peaks located at 32.8, 39.0, 53.7, 65.7, and 69.7° attributed to (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) of Ag(I) are observed. After being reduced by H2, the XRD pattern of the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 displayed considerable changes, several signals at 38.3, 44.3, 64.5, and 77.3° assigned to (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes of metallic Ag appears [15,35]. Such result indicates that Ag(I) have been successfully loaded onto the POP and was completely reduced. The results of the XRD analysis suggests that dispersion of the Ag is not a monatomic state, which could attribute to the partial hydrolysis of silver ion under the weak alkaline conditions to Ag2O NPs that chemisorb on the POP surface through the N atom (see in Fig. 4b). The SEM and TEM images of the POP shows that the POP carriers is a regular spherical particle with a diameter of about 2–4 µm (Fig. 2a and d). After loading Ag(I) ions, Ag2O NPs were formed on the surface of POP, and the morphological features of catalysts no obvious changes after reduced Ag2O NPs to Ag NPs (Fig. 2b, c and e, f). Nevertheless, the size of Ag NPs on the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 is 20.73 ± 4.44 nm (Fig. 2k and Ɩ) is slightly larger than the size of Ag2O NPs on the Ag(I)@POP-6.52 (17.19 ± 2.47 nm, Fig. 2h and i), which may be due to the migration and aggregation of Ag NPs during the process of reduction. To further identify the surface structure of Ag species, the HRTEM micrograph of Ag(I)@POP-6.52 and Ag(0)@POP-6.52 are shown in Fig. 2(j and m). As a result, the Ag2O was detected on Ag(I)@POP-6.52 by the reflection of (100) with a spacing of d = 0.252 nm and Ag0 was detected on Ag(0)@POP-6.52 by the (111) reflection, corresponding to the spacing d = 0.225 nm [33]. The results of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of catalysts is presented in Table 2. The SBET, pore volume and average pore diameter of Ag(I)@POP-6.52 is lower than POP which suggests that a small part of pores were closed after Ag(I) loaded. However, the SBET, pore volume and average pore diameter of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 and R-Ag(0)@POP-6.52 are close to the Ag(I)@POP-6.52, suggesting that pore structure of this catalyst is quite stable, even under the heat treatment and catalytic conditions. Furthermore, the isotherm of POP, Ag(I)@POP-6.52 and Ag(0)@POP-6.52 shows a sharp increase in the volume of N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of 0.4, which indicates that POP, Ag(I)@POP-6.52 and Ag(0)@POP-6.52 are characteristic for mesoporous structures (Fig. 3) [40]. XPS analysis was further used to confirm the structure of the POP, Ag(I)@POP-6.52 and Ag(0)@POP-6.52, and the results are presented in Fig. 4. The XPS survey scan of the POP shows peaks at binding energy (BE) around 400 and 295 eV, respectively corresponding to the expected BE values for nitrogen (N 1 s) and carbon (C 1 s) [33,34]. For the Ag(I)@POP-6.52 and Ag(0)@POP-6.52, in addition to N 1 s and carbon C 1 s, the other three binding energies are observed about at 532, 374 and 368 eV, which attribute to the oxygen (1 s), silver 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 [30]. To reveal a better insight into the interaction between Ag and POP, the N 1 s spectra are shown in Fig. 4b. As can be seen, the N 1 s binding energy of POP is located at 400.5 eV, nevertheless, the N 1 s binding energies of Ag(I)@POP-6.52 and Ag(0)@POP-6.52 are observed at 401.6 and 401.2 eV. Shifts to a higher binding energy are attributed to decreased electron density of the N group since the Ag NPs anchored on [30,34]. Based on the N 1 s XPS results, we believe that the Ag NPs chemisorb on the POP surface mainly through the N atom. The Ag 3d XPS results of Ag(I)@POP-6.52 and Ag(0)@POP-6.52 are shown in Fig. 4c, two peaks at approximately 374.1 and 368.1 eV are observed (Ag(I)@POP-6.52), expectedly, a downshift of Ag 3d binding energy is observed after reduced to Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (373.4 and 367.5 eV) since increased electron density of the AgNP [15,34]. 3.2 Catalysts and bases screening Catalytic oxidation of HMF to HMFCA was first conducted by different type of silver catalysts including Ag2O, Ag2S, AgBr, AgF, CH₃COOAg and Ag(0)@POP-6.52. The blank experiment shows that 59.8% conversion of HMF was achieved with low HMFCA selectivity (10.9%) and carbon balance (46.7%) ( Table 3, entry 1), indicating that HMF could not be converted to HMFCA without an efficient catalytic system. As reported in the literature, HMF undergoes degradation or poly-merization to side products such as humins in basic media [18,19,41]. Comparably, a HMF conversion from 59.7% to 91.8% with HMFCA selectivity higher than 85% were observed using different types of catalysts under the same amount of silver atom (HMF/Ag = 2:0.1). Furthermore, only HMFCA was detected (Entries 2–7) with different silver compounds as catalyst, which indicates that Ag could not be able to further oxidize HMFCA into FFCA and FDCA as compared to noble metals such as Ru, Pd, Pt, and Au [42]. For Ag(0)@POP-x (Entries 7–10), the HMFCA selectivity and HMF conversion follows the variety of x value, i.e. Ag(0)@POP-1.21 (98.2%, 99.9%) > Ag(0)@POP-2.18 (98.0%, 99.8%) > Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (97.4%, 99.8%) > Ag(0)@POP-7.98 (96.3%, 95.2%), which indicates that the higher loading lead to a lower utilization of Ag atoms. Taking into account the cost of silver atoms and POP carriers, Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was regarded as the optimal catalyst and used for subsequent experiments for HMF oxidation to HMFCA. Compare with the result of POP (Entry 11) and the commercially available silver catalyst (Entry 2–6) suggesting that the Ag species is the actual catalytic sites and the activity could be improved after supported onto the POP. For a comparison, three other supported silver catalyst Ag@TiO2, Ag@MCM-41, and Ag@Al2O3 were also used for HMF oxidation (Entry 12–14). Among these three catalyst, Ag@TiO2 shows the optimum catalytic properties, 94.6% conversion of HMF with 91.6% selectivity of HMFCA was achieved. However, Ag@TiO2 shows a relatively weak catalytic stability, HMFCA selectivity reduced by 6.8% after first cycle, that may be due to the humins deposition on the micro-environment of the acids sites on TiO2 [43]. Based on the above results, POP is a suitable carrier for Ag NPs catalysts. Quantitative conversion of HMF could be achieved with moderate HMFCA yield (57.6% and 51.7%) using a strong base such as NaOH and KOH for HMF oxidation ( Table 4, entry 1, 2). However, only 11.7% HMF was converted with 93.2% HMFCA selectivity in the absence of any alkali (Entry 6). These results suggests that the oxidation of HMF to HMFCA hardly happened without any alkali and strong base could promote HMF conversion, concomitantly with high degree of polymerization [15,33]. Subsequently, in order to decrease the alkalinity of the base, some weak bases were screened within the scope of Na2CO3, NaHCO3 and CH₃COONa. CH₃COONa and NaHCO3 presented poor HMF conversions (26.7% and 32.3%) and HMFCA yield (24.6% and 29.8%), but a high HMFCA selectivity (92.1% and 92.3%) under identical conditions (Entry 3, 4). These results clearly indicates that either too strong or too weak alkalinity is unfavorable for the formation of HMFCA. Interestingly, 99.8% HMF conversion and 97.2% HMFCA yield (97.4% HMFCA selectivity) were provided when Na2CO3 was used (Entry 5), significantly higher than that of CH₃COONa and NaHCO3. Thus, Na2CO3 was regarded as the best candidate base, which was used for subsequent experiments for HMF oxidation to HMFCA. 3.3 Reaction conditions Generally, the properties of the solvent, such as the polarity, dielectric constant, steric hindrance potential, and acid–base properties, have a significant impact on a chemical reaction [44]. The aerobic oxidation of HMF over Ag(0)@POP-6.52 catalyst was therefore initially carried out in a range of solvents in order to inspect the effect of the solvent. As shown in Table 5, the solvent had a considerable effect on HMF conversion and HMFCA selectivity. Na2CO3, an ionic compound, has poor solubility in solvents with low dielectric constant, thus the HMF was hardly converted in toluene or THF since the alkalinity of the reaction medium is relatively weak (Entry 1, 2). It was interesting to find that both HMF conversion and product yields increased with increasing the solvent polarity (Entry 3–8). A maximum HMFCA yield of 97.2% with a HMF conversion of 99.8% was achieved in the H2O. In addition to high yield, water also has the advantages such as low cost and toxicity. Therefore, we concluded that H2O is favorable for the Ag(0)@POP-6.52-catalyzed conversion of HMF to HMFCA. With regard to the base dosage, as shown in Fig. 5a, the HMF conversion and HMFCA yield were increased by using an elevated base dosage (0–4 equiv). Almost quantitative conversion of HMF with a 97.2% selectivity of HMFCA could be achieved while the base dosage increased to 2 equiv. However, further increased the base dosage exceeds 2 equiv shows a decreased catalyst performance may be ascribed to the promotion of unfavorable reactions under strong alkalinity, such as condensation of HMF leading to the formation of insoluble humins [15,33]. Thus, 2 equiv of Na2CO3 is consequently selected for further research as the optimum base dosage. As shown in Fig. 5b, the HMF conversion and HMFCA yield are obviously dependent on the oxygen pressure. Without pressurized oxygen, the yield of HMFCA was only 8.6% with about 50% conversion of HMF. This may be due to the O2 concentration in the reaction solution is quiet low. It is observed that HMF conversion and HMFCA yield increased gradually with the increases of oxygen pressure since the O2 concentration in the reaction solution gradually increasing. However, the oxygen pressure higher than 2.0 MPa showed no obvious improvement for the yield of HMFCA. Thus, the optimal oxygen pressure is regarded as 2.0 MPa, which was used for the subsequent experiments. Different dosage of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 were used in order to inspected the effect of catalyst loading on the HMF conversion and HMFCA yield, while keeping the other operating conditions constant. As shown in Fig. 5c, the catalyst dosage has a significant effect on the HMF conversion and HMFCA yield. Without Ag(0)@POP-6.52 addition, an HMFCA yield of 6.5% and the HMF conversion of 59.8% were achieved, showing the poor efficiency of HMF oxidation to HMFCA under only thermal treatment in this reaction system. By contrast, 38.3% HMFCA was produced with 67.4% HMF converted after 1 mol% Ag(0)@POP-6.52 (based on the silver atom) was added. When the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 dosage was increased to 5 mol%, almost quantitative conversion of HMF (99.8%) was observed, and the HMFCA yield also significantly increased to 97.2%. A further increase of the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 dosage only resulted in a negligible increase of the HMFCA yield and HMF conversion. Thus, 5 mol% of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 is an efficient catalyst loading for the conversion of HMF into HMFCA. The effect of temperature and time on the HMF conversion and HMFCA yield were studied by interval sampling in the temperature range of 25–120 °C. As shown in Fig. 5d, the HMF conversion was only 57.5%, 73.1%, 88.2 after reaction at 25 °C, 40 °C, and 60 °C for 480 min. By contrast, almost complete conversion of HMF could be achieved within 240 min when the temperature was increased to 80 °C. Further elevating the reaction temperature to 100 °C and 120 °C obviously shortened the reaction time to 90 min and 60 min, which indicates that high temperatures are favorable for HMF conversion over the catalysis of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. A maximum HMFCA yield of 97.2% was obtained at 100 °C for 90 min, and an evident decline was observed after prolonging the reaction time or elevating the reaction temperature. The lower yield of HMFCA at the high temperatures or long reaction times may be ascribed to the promotion of unfavorable reactions, such as condensation of HMF leading to the formation of insoluble humins [45]. Thus, 100 °C and 90 min are regarded as the optimal reaction temperature and time, which were used for subsequent experiments. 3.4 Recyclability of the Ag(0)@POP Active sites leaching and aggregation, the two major issues of Ag NPs catalyst recyclability in the HMF oxidation [33–35], were investigated by Ag(0)@POP-6.52 filtration and recovery, respectively. Ag NPs leaching test was conducted by Ag(0)@POP-6.52 filtration after running the HMF oxidation for about 30 min at 100 °C, and then continued the reaction for another 90 min with the absence of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. As shown in Fig. 6a, almost no further increases of HMFCA yield is observed indicating that no Ag NPs of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was leached into the reaction medium, which is consistent with the result of silver content detection before and after reaction (Table 2). The catalytic stability of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was further investigated by batch reaction of HMF oxidation at 100 °C for 90 min to evaluate the catalytic efficiency. After each run, the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was recovered by filtration, washed with water and dried under vacuum at 80 °C for overnight, and then used for next run. Impressively, no apparent decrease of HMF conversion and HMFCA yield was observed even after five times recycling (Fig. 6b). The fresh and five times reused Ag(0)@POP-6.52 were further characterized by SEM, XRD, and FT-IR. As shown in the SEM ( Fig. 7a, b) images, the structure stability of the reused Ag(0)@POP-6.52 catalyst after five successive runs was found to be positive. No obvious collapse and aggregation the of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was observed compared to the fresh one. Meanwhile, from the patterns of XRD (Fig. 7c) and FT-IR (Fig. 7d), it can be seen that the recovered catalyst showed the same characteristic peaks to the fresh one, which indicates that the structure of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 catalyst is highly stable even under harsh conditions. Furthermore, the Ag content in the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 after five cycles was 6.43 wt% according to ICP-OES analysis, which is close to that in the fresh one (6.52 wt%), suggesting that no apparent leaching of Ag NPs was occurred during the reaction, which is coincided with the result of Ag(0)@POP-6.52 filtration test. 3.5 Oxidation of other aldehydes With the aim to verify the applicability of Ag(0)@POP-6.52, the present system was further examined for the oxidation of other aldehydes. As shown in Table 6, the aldehydes examined underwent smooth transformation to afford the corresponding acid in excellent yields under the present system. DFF and FFCA, both important intermediates for HMF oxidation to FDCA, were efficient conversion to FDCA in remarkable yields (higher than 95%, entry 1, 2). Furoic acid, a raw materials for FDCA preparing [46,47], could be quantitative produced from furfural under the catalysis of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. Noted that Ag(0)@POP-6.52 could selectively oxidize the aldehyde group in the citronellal without affecting the CC groups, and cinnamic acid could be almost quantitatively obtained (Entry 7). 3.6 Plausible reaction mechanism According to the previous reports [15,35,48] and based on our test, an plausible reaction mechanism has been proposed in Fig. 8 involving Ag, OH− and O2. Ag is oxidized to Ag+ by O2 and subsequently reduced by the aldehyde group on HMF, which is oxidized to HMFCA. The reaction begins with the oxidation of aldehyde group on HMF to form a radical cation (intermediate A) followed by the nucleophilically attacked by hydroxide ion (OH−) on the carbocation to form a tetrahedral intermediate (intermediate B). Further, a gem-diol intermediate (intermediate C) is formed via hydrogen shift and then one of the hydroxyl groups on intermediate C is attacked by hydroxide ion (OH−) to form a radical-anion (intermediate D). Finally, the single electron on the intermediate D is transferred to Ag+, resulting in the formation of a carboxylic acid group (HMFCA) and then the end-product carboxylate anion (HMFC−) is formed after the carboxyl hydrogen is subtracted by the hydroxide ion (OH−). Oxygen-mediated oxidation of Ag0 (Eq. 4) is a pivotal step since that Ag+ mediated the single electron transfer during the aldehyde oxidation, such ideas are in accordance with the obtained results that only 8.6% yield of HMFCA with about 50% conversion of HMF was achieved without pressurized oxygen (Fig. 5b). Hydroxide ion (OH−), produced by the hydrolysis of carbonate ions (Eq. 5, endothermic reaction), is an important species in the process of HMF oxidation since it involved in three important processes. Such proposals are consistent with the results that the factors which could increase the concentration of hydroxide ions, such as base dosage and temperature has a positive impact on the HMF conversion of (Fig. 5a, d). Interestingly, the pH value of the reaction mixture was no significant change (from 11.8 to 10.9), thus the OH− species is likely to be regenerated via O 2 • − reacts with H2O (Eq. 6). (4) Ag 0 + O 2 → Ag + + O 2 • − (5) CO 3 2 − + H 2 O ⇄ HCO 3 − + OH − (6) 4 O 2 • − + 2 H 2 O → 4 OH − + 3 O 2 4 Conclusions In summary, Ag(0)@POP-x, a porphyrin-based porous organic polymer-supported Ag nanoparticle catalysts, have been designed and synthesized by the reaction pathway of Ag+ coordination with POP followed by hydrogen reduction. In which, Ag(0)@POP-6.52 proved to be an efficient catalyst for aerobic oxidation of HMF to HMFCA. Upon optimization, 97.2% HMFCA yield was achieved in the presence of Na2CO3 (2.0 eq) and O2 (2.0 MPa) at 100 °C for 90 min. High efficiency and selectivity, recyclability and good applicability were observed for the present catalyst. Future work about further applications of this catalyst is currently under investigation in our group. coredata.dc:description: A series of porphyrin-based porous organic polymer-supported Ag nanoparticle, Ag(0)@POP-x were prepared by the reaction pathway of ion coordination followed by hydrogen reduction. The resulting composite Ag(0)@POP-6.52 shows excellent catalytic performance toward the selective oxidation of HMF to HMFCA, and an impressive HMFCA yield of 97.2% (Na2CO3 2 eq, O2 2.0 MPa 90 min, 100 °C). Analysis techniques such as ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, and XPS was employed to characterize the structure and properties of Ag(0)@POP-6.52. The reaction conditions including the type of base and solvent, base and catalyst dosage, oxygen pressure, reaction temperature and time were studied in detail to improve the yield of HMFCA. Furthermore, the catalytic stability of the Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was evaluated by leaching and reusing tests, the results shows that the catalyst has good stability and robustness structure. Finally, the other aldehydes oxidation over Ag(0)@POP-6.52 was tested for investigation the substrate scope of Ag(0)@POP-6.52.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid over porphyrin-based porous organic polymer-supported Ag nanoparticle catalysts
